problem: If $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are both seventh-degree polynomials in $t$, what is the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$?
vllm_responses: We have $p(t) = at^7$ and $q(t) = CT^7$ for some constants $A$, $B$, and $C$ and $t\neq 0$. When we multiply these two polynomials, the degree of the resulting polynomial will be the sum of the degrees of the two polynomials. In other words, it will be $7+7=14$. Therefore, the degree of $p(t) \cdot q(t)$ is $\boxed{14}$.

The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of $t$ that appears in the polynomial.
When we multiply two polynomials, the degree of the resulting polynomial will be the highest of the degrees of the two polynomials.
So, the degree of $p(t) \cdot q(t)$ will be the highest of the degrees of $p(t)$ and $q(t)$.
Since $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are both seventh-degree polynomials, the degree of $p(t) \cdot q(t)$ will be $7 + 7 = \boxed{14}$.
The answer is: 14

When we multiply polynomial $p(t)$ and $q(t)$, we add the exponents of each term together. Since both $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are seventh-degree polynomials, the highest degree term will have an exponent of 7 when multiplied together. Additionally, the exponents of the other terms will also be added together.
Therefore, the degree of the resulting polynomial will be $7+7=\boxed{14}$.

Let's consider the general form of a seventh-degree polynomial. It can be written as:
$p(t) = a_7t^7 + a_6t^6 + \ldots + a_1t + a_0$
$q(t) = b_7t^7 + b_6t^6 + \ldots + b_1t + b_0$
When we multiply the two polynomials, we get:
$p(t)\cdot q(t) = (a_7t^7 + a_6t^6 + \ldots + a_1t + a_0)(b_7t^7 + b_6t^6 + \ldots + b_1t + b_0)$
Expanding this expression, we get:
$p(t)\cdot q(t) = a_7b_7t^{7+7} + a_7b_6t^{6+7} + \ldots + a_7b_1t + a_7b_0 + a_6b_7t^{6+7} + \ldots + a_6b_1t + a_6b_0 + \ldots$
Simplifying further, we can see that all the terms with degree $7$ will cancel out and we are left with:
$p(t)\cdot q(t) = a_6b_7t^{13} + a_6b_6t^{12} + \ldots + a_6b_1t + a_6b_0$
The degree of the polynomial $p(t)\cdot q(t)$ is $13$ because the highest degree term is $t^{13}$. 
So, the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$ is $13$.
The answer is: 13

The degree of a polynomial is the highest power of the variable that appears in the polynomial. Since both $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are seventh-degree polynomials in $t$, the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$ will be the sum of the degrees of $p(t)$ and $q(t)$, which is $7+7=\boxed{14}$.
The answer is: 14

In general, the degree of a polynomial from the product of two polynomials of degree $n$ and $m$ is $n+m+1$.
In this case, since both $p(t)$ and $q(t)$ are seventh-degree polynomials, the degree of $p(t)\cdot q(t)$ would be $7+7+1=\boxed{15}$.
The answer is: 15
